ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a much deeper understanding of both the broad spectrum and the individual nuances of Modern European Jewish history. Particulary in subject matter regarding emancipation, politics, assimilation, and nationalism.

I really enjoyed this class, and felt that I gained a lot of insight on the social, economic, and political history of Jewish people living in Europe in the "modern era" as well as on the scholarship on this period of Jewish history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It is an intense reading load, but I think that this is a strength for those who take it seriously. I learned a huge amount in one semester, but I really engaged with the readings. David Sorkin has a pedagogical model somewhat different than the average seminar course, such that he is very focused on learning content. Comparatively, I learned much more in this class for this reason, but there is less focus on student discussion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. I think it would be easier if the student had some prior knowledge of both Jewish history/culture and European history, but I don't think that it's necessarily requisite.
